SeriesTitle: Expression data of Arabidopsis grown under low or sufficient nitrogen availability
SeriesDescription: Nitrogen availability in the soil is a major determinant of crop yield. While the application of fertilizer can substantially increase the yield on poor soils, it also causes nitrate pollution of water resources and high costs for farmers. Increasing the nitrogen use efficiency in crop plants is a necessary step to implement low input agricultural systems. We exploited the genetic diversity present in the world-wide Arabidopsis thaliana population to study adaptive growth patterns and changes in gene expression associated with chronic low nitrate stress, with the aim to identify biomarkers associated with good plant performance under low nitrate availability.;	Transcription and epigenetic factors were identified as important players in the adaptatiion to limited nitrogen in a global gene expression analysis using the Affymetrix ATH1 chip.
SeriesOverallDesign: Six lines with contrasting growth characteristics on low N were used for gene expression analysis, the accessions El-0 and Fei-0, and the mixed RILs KB006, NG064, NG087, SG063. For each line, root and shoot samples were taken from plants grown on 0.4 mM or 9 mM nitrate. Three biological replicates were used per organ and treatment, in total 72 samples. One replicate consisted of a pool of 30 plants harvested from three plates.
SampleTitle: El-0 shoot on low N, biological rep 1
SampleAttributes: SOURCE : [Arabidopsis shoot after 21 days growth on 0.4 mM nitrate]; CHARACTESTICS : [ tissue: shoot;	treatment: 0.4 mM nitrate;	genotype: accession El-0 N1134;	age: 21 days after sowing;	culture: synthetic agar medium with 1% sucrose]; LABEL : [ biotin]; TREATMENT : [ The control medium (9 mM nitrate) contained 5 mM KNO3 and 2 mM Ca(NO3)2, the low nitrogen medium (0.4 mM nitrate) contained 0.2 mM Ca(NO3)2 and 5 mM KCl.]; EXTRACTION : [ Total RNA was isolated using the adapted hot-borate method (Wan & Wilkins, Analytical Biochemistry 1994, 223:7-12)]; PROTOCOL_LABEL : [ Performed by Atlas Biolabs, Berlin, Germany, according to Affymetrix standard protocols.;	Biotinylated cRNA were prepared with the MessageAmpII-96 aRNA Kit (Ambion, Cat-No. 1819 / Manual Version: 0511) from 1 ug total RNA]; HYBRIDIZATION_LABEL : [ Performed by Atlas Biolabs, Berlin, Germany, according to Affymetrix standard protocols.;	Following fragmentation, 15 ug of cRNA were hybridized for 16 hr at 45 C on GeneChip ATH1 Genome Array. GeneChips were washed and stained in the Affymetrix Fluidics Station 450 with wash protocol EukGEWS2v4_450]; GSM_PROCESSING : [ The data were analyzed with R/Bioconductor using the R packages affy, limma, simpleaffy, and affyPLM. Quality was controlled using fitPLM (affyPLM package) and qc (simpleaffy package). Data was normalized with GC-RMA algorithm (affy package). Differential expression was detected by fitting linear models using lmFit (limma package) to the contrasts between plus and minus nitrogen samples. Resulting p-values were controlled for multiple error correction using false discovery rate (FDR).];

SeriesTitle: Expression data of Arabidopsis grown under low or sufficient nitrogen availability
SeriesDescription: Nitrogen availability in the soil is a major determinant of crop yield. While the application of fertilizer can substantially increase the yield on poor soils, it also causes nitrate pollution of water resources and high costs for farmers. Increasing the nitrogen use efficiency in crop plants is a necessary step to implement low input agricultural systems. We exploited the genetic diversity present in the world-wide Arabidopsis thaliana population to study adaptive growth patterns and changes in gene expression associated with chronic low nitrate stress, with the aim to identify biomarkers associated with good plant performance under low nitrate availability.;	Transcription and epigenetic factors were identified as important players in the adaptatiion to limited nitrogen in a global gene expression analysis using the Affymetrix ATH1 chip.

Increasing the nitrogen use efficiency in crop plants is a necessary step to implement low input agricultural systems. We exploited the genetic diversity present in the world-wide Arabidopsis thaliana population to study adaptive growth patterns and changes in gene expression associated with chronic low nitrate stress, with the aim to identify biomarkers associated with good plant performance under low nitrate availability.;	Transcription and epigenetic factors were identified as important players in the adaptatiion to limited nitrogen in a global gene expression analysis using the Affymetrix ATH1 chip.
SeriesOverallDesign: Six lines with contrasting growth characteristics on low N were used for gene expression analysis, the accessions El-0 and Fei-0, and the mixed RILs KB006, NG064, NG087, SG063. For each line, root and shoot samples were taken from plants grown on 0.4 mM or 9 mM nitrate. Three biological replicates were used per organ and treatment, in total 72 samples. One replicate consisted of a pool of 30 plants harvested from three plates.
SampleTitle: Fei-0 root on sufficient N, biological rep 1
SampleAttributes: SOURCE : [Arabidopsis root after 21 days growth on 9 mM nitrate]; CHARACTESTICS : [ tissue: root;	treatment: 9 mM nitrate;	genotype: accession Fei-0 CS76412;	age: 21 days after sowing;	culture: synthetic agar medium with 1% sucrose]; LABEL : [ biotin]; TREATMENT : [ The control medium (9 mM nitrate) contained 5 mM KNO3 and 2 mM Ca(NO3)2, the low nitrogen medium (0.4 mM nitrate) contained 0.2 mM Ca(NO3)2 and 5 mM KCl.]; EXTRACTION : [ Total RNA was isolated using the adapted hot-borate method (Wan & Wilkins, Analytical Biochemistry 1994, 223:7-12)]; PROTOCOL_LABEL : [ Performed by Atlas Biolabs, Berlin, Germany, according to Affymetrix standard protocols.;	Biotinylated cRNA were prepared with the MessageAmpII-96 aRNA Kit (Ambion, Cat-No. 1819 / Manual Version: 0511) from 1 ug total RNA]; HYBRIDIZATION_LABEL : [ Performed by Atlas Biolabs, Berlin, Germany, according to Affymetrix standard protocols.;	Following fragmentation, 15 ug of cRNA were hybridized for 16 hr at 45 C on GeneChip ATH1 Genome Array. GeneChips were washed and stained in the Affymetrix Fluidics Station 450 with wash protocol EukGEWS2v4_450]; GSM_PROCESSING : [ The data were analyzed with R/Bioconductor using the R packages affy, limma, simpleaffy, and affyPLM. Quality was controlled using fitPLM (affyPLM package) and qc (simpleaffy package). Data was normalized with GC-RMA algorithm (affy package). Differential expression was detected by fitting linear models using lmFit (limma package) to the contrasts between plus and minus nitrogen samples. Resulting p-values were controlled for multiple error correction using false discovery rate (FDR).];

SeriesDescription: Nitrogen availability in the soil is a major determinant of crop yield. While the application of fertilizer can substantially increase the yield on poor soils, it also causes nitrate pollution of water resources and high costs for farmers. Increasing the nitrogen use efficiency in crop plants is a necessary step to implement low input agricultural systems. We exploited the genetic diversity present in the world-wide Arabidopsis thaliana population to study adaptive growth patterns and changes in gene expression associated with chronic low nitrate stress, with the aim to identify biomarkers associated with good plant performance under low nitrate availability.;	Transcription and epigenetic factors were identified as important players in the adaptatiion to limited nitrogen in a global gene expression analysis using the Affymetrix ATH1 chip.
SeriesOverallDesign: Six lines with contrasting growth characteristics on low N were used for gene expression analysis, the accessions El-0 and Fei-0, and the mixed RILs KB006, NG064, NG087, SG063. For each line, root and shoot samples were taken from plants grown on 0.4 mM or 9 mM nitrate. Three biological replicates were used per organ and treatment, in total 72 samples. One replicate consisted of a pool of 30 plants harvested from three plates.
SampleTitle: NG064-0 root on low N, biological rep 1
SampleAttributes: SOURCE : [Arabidopsis root after 21 days growth on 0.4 mM nitrate]; CHARACTESTICS : [ tissue: root;	treatment: 0.4 mM nitrate;	genotype: RIL NG064 (Nok-3 x Ga-0);	age: 21 days after sowing;	culture: synthetic agar medium with 1% sucrose]; LABEL : [ biotin]; TREATMENT : [ The control medium (9 mM nitrate) contained 5 mM KNO3 and 2 mM Ca(NO3)2, the low nitrogen medium (0.4 mM nitrate) contained 0.2 mM Ca(NO3)2 and 5 mM KCl.]; EXTRACTION : [ Total RNA was isolated using the adapted hot-borate method (Wan & Wilkins, Analytical Biochemistry 1994, 223:7-12)]; PROTOCOL_LABEL : [ Performed by Atlas Biolabs, Berlin, Germany, according to Affymetrix standard protocols.;	Biotinylated cRNA were prepared with the MessageAmpII-96 aRNA Kit (Ambion, Cat-No. 1819 / Manual Version: 0511) from 1 ug total RNA]; HYBRIDIZATION_LABEL : [ Performed by Atlas Biolabs, Berlin, Germany, according to Affymetrix standard protocols.;	Following fragmentation, 15 ug of cRNA were hybridized for 16 hr at 45 C on GeneChip ATH1 Genome Array. GeneChips were washed and stained in the Affymetrix Fluidics Station 450 with wash protocol EukGEWS2v4_450]; GSM_PROCESSING : [ The data were analyzed with R/Bioconductor using the R packages affy, limma, simpleaffy, and affyPLM. Quality was controlled using fitPLM (affyPLM package) and qc (simpleaffy package). Data was normalized with GC-RMA algorithm (affy package). Differential expression was detected by fitting linear models using lmFit (limma package) to the contrasts between plus and minus nitrogen samples. Resulting p-values were controlled for multiple error correction using false discovery rate (FDR).];

SeriesDescription: Nitrogen availability in the soil is a major determinant of crop yield. While the application of fertilizer can substantially increase the yield on poor soils, it also causes nitrate pollution of water resources and high costs for farmers. Increasing the nitrogen use efficiency in crop plants is a necessary step to implement low input agricultural systems. We exploited the genetic diversity present in the world-wide Arabidopsis thaliana population to study adaptive growth patterns and changes in gene expression associated with chronic low nitrate stress, with the aim to identify biomarkers associated with good plant performance under low nitrate availability.;	Transcription and epigenetic factors were identified as important players in the adaptatiion to limited nitrogen in a global gene expression analysis using the Affymetrix ATH1 chip.
SeriesOverallDesign: Six lines with contrasting growth characteristics on low N were used for gene expression analysis, the accessions El-0 and Fei-0, and the mixed RILs KB006, NG064, NG087, SG063. For each line, root and shoot samples were taken from plants grown on 0.4 mM or 9 mM nitrate. Three biological replicates were used per organ and treatment, in total 72 samples. One replicate consisted of a pool of 30 plants harvested from three plates.
SampleTitle: SG063-0 shoot on sufficient N, biological rep 1
SampleAttributes: SOURCE : [Arabidopsis shoot after 21 days growth on 9 mM nitrate]; CHARACTESTICS : [ tissue: shoot;	treatment: 9 mM nitrate;	genotype: RIL SG063 (Sorbo x Gy-0);	age: 21 days after sowing;	culture: synthetic agar medium with 1% sucrose]; LABEL : [ biotin]; TREATMENT : [ The control medium (9 mM nitrate) contained 5 mM KNO3 and 2 mM Ca(NO3)2, the low nitrogen medium (0.4 mM nitrate) contained 0.2 mM Ca(NO3)2 and 5 mM KCl.]; EXTRACTION : [ Total RNA was isolated using the adapted hot-borate method (Wan & Wilkins, Analytical Biochemistry 1994, 223:7-12)]; PROTOCOL_LABEL : [ Performed by Atlas Biolabs, Berlin, Germany, according to Affymetrix standard protocols.;	Biotinylated cRNA were prepared with the MessageAmpII-96 aRNA Kit (Ambion, Cat-No. 1819 / Manual Version: 0511) from 1 ug total RNA]; HYBRIDIZATION_LABEL : [ Performed by Atlas Biolabs, Berlin, Germany, according to Affymetrix standard protocols.;	Following fragmentation, 15 ug of cRNA were hybridized for 16 hr at 45 C on GeneChip ATH1 Genome Array. GeneChips were washed and stained in the Affymetrix Fluidics Station 450 with wash protocol EukGEWS2v4_450]; GSM_PROCESSING : [ The data were analyzed with R/Bioconductor using the R packages affy, limma, simpleaffy, and affyPLM. Quality was controlled using fitPLM (affyPLM package) and qc (simpleaffy package). Data was normalized with GC-RMA algorithm (affy package). Differential expression was detected by fitting linear models using lmFit (limma package) to the contrasts between plus and minus nitrogen samples. Resulting p-values were controlled for multiple error correction using false discovery rate (FDR).];

SeriesTitle: Expression data from Arabidopsis shoots and roots
SeriesDescription: Regulation of genes in shoots and roots and Arabidopsis in response to Zn-deficiency in wild-type and hma2 hma4 mutants plants;	We used microarrays to determine co-regulated genes in the roots of Zn deficient wild-type plants with hma2 hma4 plants from control conditions. These co-regulated genes are candidates for regulation by a systemic signal
SeriesOverallDesign: Shoots and roots of wild-type plants grown in control and Zn-deficient conditions were harvested at 7 weeks of age, 3 weeks after transfer to -Zn or control media. Shoot and roots of wild-type and hma2 hma4 plants were harvested after 21 days of growth
SampleTitle: 7 week old WT Shoots Control Rep 1
SampleDescription: Gene expression data from Arabidopsis
SampleAttributes: SOURCE : [Shoot]; CHARACTESTICS : [ age: 7 week old;	condition: Control;	genotype: WT;	tissue: Shoot]; LABEL : [ biotin]; TREATMENT : [ In the week old control vs. Zn-deficiency experiment, after 4 weeks in control conditions plants transferred to either control or Zn-deficient media for a further 3 weeks. 7 day old wild-type and hma2 hma4 seedlings were transferred from control media to vertical plates containing control media for a further 14 days growth]; EXTRACTION : [ Shoot and root tissue was snap-frozen in liquid nitrogen and ground with a mortar and pestle. ~ 500mg of tissue was applied to the QiaShredder column, and RNA extracted using the Qiagen Plant RNAeasy Kit and protocol]; PROTOCOL_LABEL : [ Biotinylated cRNA were prepared according to the standard Affymetrix protocol at Gene Core ,EMBL Heidelberg]; HYBRIDIZATION_LABEL : [ Hybridisation was performed according to the manufacturers instructions at Gene Core, EMBL Heidelberg]; GSM_PROCESSING : [ All data were imported into Genespring (Version 8, Agilent Technologies), and a MAS5 summarization/normalization performed. To account for random fluctuations that influence the signal intensity of lowly expressed probes, entities in 25th percentile of signal intensities in all microarray hybridizations were filtered out.;	Probe sets were identified that showed a 2-fold or larger average difference between conditions or between genotypes. Probe sets of interest were further narrowed down by selecting only those that showed a 2-fold or larger difference in each of both replicate experiments. These data were then subjected to an unpaired Mann-Whitney test with a cut-off value of P < 0.2.];

SeriesOverallDesign: Shoots and roots of wild-type plants grown in control and Zn-deficient conditions were harvested at 7 weeks of age, 3 weeks after transfer to -Zn or control media. Shoot and roots of wild-type and hma2 hma4 plants were harvested after 21 days of growth
SampleTitle: 7 week old WT Roots Control Rep 1
SampleDescription: Gene expression data from Arabidopsis
SampleAttributes: SOURCE : [Root]; CHARACTESTICS : [ age: 7 week old;	condition: Control;	genotype: WT;	tissue: Root]; LABEL : [ biotin]; TREATMENT : [ In the week old control vs. Zn-deficiency experiment, after 4 weeks in control conditions plants transferred to either control or Zn-deficient media for a further 3 weeks. 7 day old wild-type and hma2 hma4 seedlings were transferred from control media to vertical plates containing control media for a further 14 days growth]; EXTRACTION : [ Shoot and root tissue was snap-frozen in liquid nitrogen and ground with a mortar and pestle. ~ 500mg of tissue was applied to the QiaShredder column, and RNA extracted using the Qiagen Plant RNAeasy Kit and protocol]; PROTOCOL_LABEL : [ Biotinylated cRNA were prepared according to the standard Affymetrix protocol at Gene Core ,EMBL Heidelberg]; HYBRIDIZATION_LABEL : [ Hybridisation was performed according to the manufacturers instructions at Gene Core, EMBL Heidelberg]; GSM_PROCESSING : [ All data were imported into Genespring (Version 8, Agilent Technologies), and a MAS5 summarization/normalization performed. To account for random fluctuations that influence the signal intensity of lowly expressed probes, entities in 25th percentile of signal intensities in all microarray hybridizations were filtered out.;	Probe sets were identified that showed a 2-fold or larger average difference between conditions or between genotypes. Probe sets of interest were further narrowed down by selecting only those that showed a 2-fold or larger difference in each of both replicate experiments. These data were then subjected to an unpaired Mann-Whitney test with a cut-off value of P < 0.2.];

SeriesTitle: Vitis Myb14 confer cold and drought tolerance by mediated nsLTP genes expression and ABA signaling passway in arabidopsis
SeriesDescription: The growth and fruit quality of grapevine are widely affected by abnormal climatic conditions such as extreme temperature. But how grapevine responds to cold stress is still largely unknown. Here we found that VaMyb14, a member of R2R3 Myb transcription factor family, was up-regulated dramatically during cold, drought and salinity treatments in Vitis amurensis, a cold and drought-hardiness wild Vitis species. Overexpression VaMyb14 in Arabidopsis increased antioxidant enzyme activity, especially POD activity, than that of the wild type and decreased the MDA content. A series of ABA metabolism and signal transduction genes in transgenic Arabidopsiswere were up-regulated in microarry results, including several nsLTPs, PP2Cs, RD29B, COR78 and other structural genes, suggesting that VaMyb14 not only affect the ABA signaling pathways, but also activates the CBF-COR independent nsLTP genes. Collectively, these results illustrate that Vitis Myb14 could represent a node of convergence regulating grapevine stress responses, including improve defence induced phytoalexin resveratrol against necrotrophic as well as drought and/or cold stress tolerance, highlighting Myb14 as a potential gene resource in future grapevine breeding.
SeriesOverallDesign: Leaves from wild-type and three transgenic lines were collected before and after 8 h cold stress. An equal amount of leaves from three independent transgenic lines that were harvested in same day was pooled as OE lines for RNA isolation. Four samples were collected, which including WT 0d, OE 0d, WT 8h and OE 8h and each sample were represented by two replicates.

SeriesTitle: Profiling primary downstream target of LBD16 in roots of Arabidopsis thaliana
SeriesDescription: Lateral roots (LRs) are formed post-embryonically and contribute to root architecture formation in vascular plants. LATERAL ORGAN BOUNDARIES-DOMAIN 16 (LBD16) is a key transcription factor to initiate LR formation functioning redundantly with related LBD members. To identify primary downstream targets of LBD16, we engineered a transgenic line with inducible LBD16 activity by expressing a fusion protein of LBD16 and rat glucocorticoid receptor (GR) under the regulation of its own regulatory region (gLBD16-GR) in the lbd16-1 lbd18-1 lbd33-1 mutant. Here we identified primary response genes of LBD16 from transcriptome analysis.
SeriesOverallDesign: Overexpression line of LBD16-Glucocorticoid Receptor (GR) driven by CaMV35S promoter in arf7 arf19 mutant was used for LBD16 induction. We collected roos from 5-day-old seedlings of 35S:LBD16:GR arf7 arf19 line 4 hours after treatment with/without dexamethazone (DEX) and cycloheximide (CHX). Two independent sets of mRNA samples for each treatment were used for this analysis
SampleTitle: gLBD16-GR_mock_rep1
SampleDescription: Gene expression data from 5-day-old gLBD16-GR roots mock treatment (4h) rep1
SampleAttributes: SOURCE : [Arabidopsis 5-day-old root]; CHARACTESTICS : [ genotype: gLBD16:GR, lbd16-1 lbd18-1 lbd33-1;	tissue: 5-day-old root;	treatment: Mock (0.1% DMSO) treatment for 4 hours]; LABEL : [ biotin]; TREATMENT : [ 5-day-old seedlins of gLBD16:GR lbd16 lbd18 lbd33 were treated with/without 2 M DEX, 10 M CHX and 1M NAA for 4 hours]; EXTRACTION : [ Total RNA was extracted with RNeasy Plant Mini Kit (QIAGEN).]; PROTOCOL_LABEL : [ Biotinylated cRNA was prepared from total RNA with GeneChip One-Cycle Target Labeling and Control Reagents (Arab-0018 to Arab-0054) or GeneChip 3' IVT Expression Kit (Arab-113-2 to Arab-124) (Affymetrix).]; HYBRIDIZATION_LABEL : [ Hybridization, washing, staining procedures were run on Fluidics Station 450 (Affymetrix) with GeneChip Hybridization, Wash, and Stain Kit (Affymetrix).]; GSM_PROCESSING : [ Data procession was performed with Expression Console Version 1.3 (Affymetrix).];

SeriesDescription: Lateral roots (LRs) are formed post-embryonically and contribute to root architecture formation in vascular plants. LATERAL ORGAN BOUNDARIES-DOMAIN 16 (LBD16) is a key transcription factor to initiate LR formation functioning redundantly with related LBD members. To identify primary downstream targets of LBD16, we engineered a transgenic line with inducible LBD16 activity by expressing a fusion protein of LBD16 and rat glucocorticoid receptor (GR) under the regulation of its own regulatory region (gLBD16-GR) in the lbd16-1 lbd18-1 lbd33-1 mutant. Here we identified primary response genes of LBD16 from transcriptome analysis.
SeriesOverallDesign: Overexpression line of LBD16-Glucocorticoid Receptor (GR) driven by CaMV35S promoter in arf7 arf19 mutant was used for LBD16 induction. We collected roos from 5-day-old seedlings of 35S:LBD16:GR arf7 arf19 line 4 hours after treatment with/without dexamethazone (DEX) and cycloheximide (CHX). Two independent sets of mRNA samples for each treatment were used for this analysis
SampleTitle: gLBD16-GR_CHX_rep1
SampleDescription: Gene expression data from 5-day-old gLBD16-GR roots CHX treatment (4h) rep1
SampleAttributes: SOURCE : [Arabidopsis 5-day-old root]; CHARACTESTICS : [ genotype: gLBD16:GR, lbd16-1 lbd18-1 lbd33-1;	tissue: 5-day-old root;	treatment: 10 M CHX treatment for 4 hours]; LABEL : [ biotin]; TREATMENT : [ 5-day-old seedlins of gLBD16:GR lbd16 lbd18 lbd33 were treated with/without 2 M DEX, 10 M CHX and 1M NAA for 4 hours]; EXTRACTION : [ Total RNA was extracted with RNeasy Plant Mini Kit (QIAGEN).]; PROTOCOL_LABEL : [ Biotinylated cRNA was prepared from total RNA with GeneChip One-Cycle Target Labeling and Control Reagents (Arab-0018 to Arab-0054) or GeneChip 3' IVT Expression Kit (Arab-113-2 to Arab-124) (Affymetrix).]; HYBRIDIZATION_LABEL : [ Hybridization, washing, staining procedures were run on Fluidics Station 450 (Affymetrix) with GeneChip Hybridization, Wash, and Stain Kit (Affymetrix).]; GSM_PROCESSING : [ Data procession was performed with Expression Console Version 1.3 (Affymetrix).];

SeriesTitle: Comparative gene expression analysis in the Arabidopsis thaliana root apex using RNA-seq and microarray transcriptome profiles
SeriesDescription: The root apex is an important section of the plant root, involved in environmental sensing and cellular development. Analyzing the gene profile of root apex in diverse environments is important and challenging, especially when the samples are limiting and precious, such as in spaceflight. The feasibility of using tiny root sections for transcriptome analysis was examined in this study.To understand the gene expression profiles of the root apex, Arabidopsis thaliana Col-0 roots were sectioned into Zone-I (0.5 mm, root cap and meristematic zone) and Zone-II (1.5 mm, transition, elongation and growth terminating zone). Gene expression was analyzed using microarray and RNA seq.Both the techniques, arrays and RNA-Seq identified 4180 common genes as differentially expressed (with > two-fold changes) between the zones. In addition, 771 unique genes and 19 novel TARs were identified by RNA-Seq as differentially expressed which were not detected in the arrays.;	Single root tip zones can be used for full transcriptome analysis; further, the root apex zones are functionally very distinct from each other. RNA-Seq provided novel information about the transcripts compared to the arrays. These data will help optimize transcriptome techniques for dealing with small, rare samples.
SeriesOverallDesign: Arabidopsis thaliana var. Columbia (COL-0) seedlings were grown on sterile solid media plates containing 0.5 % phytagel. The plates were vertically placed in growth chambers with continuous light (80-100 mol m -2) at a constant temperature of 19 C. Eight day old seedlings were harvested into RNA-later solution in a 50 mL centrifuge tubes and stored at -20 C freezer. SeriesTitle: FPX is a Novel Chemical Inducer That Promotes Callus Formation and Shoot Regeneration in Plants [auxin & cytokinin]
SeriesDescription: Auxin and cytokinin can regulate callus formation from developed plant organs and shoot regeneration from callus. The regulation of dedifferentiation and regeneration of plant cells by auxin and cytokinin stimulation was considered to be caused by the regulation of reprograming of callus cells, but the hypothesis had been argued still in now. Although elucidation of the regulatory mechanisms of callus formation and shoot regeneration has helped advance plant biotechnology research, many plant species are intractable to transformation because of difficulties with callus regulation. In this study, we identified the compound Fipexide (FPX) as a useful regulatory compound through chemical biology-based screening. Compared with the activity of auxin and cytokinin, FPX showed higher efficiency as a chemical inducer in callus formation, shoot regeneration, and Agrobacterium infection. In regards to morphology, the cellular organization of FPX-induced callus differed from that produced under auxin/cytokinin conditions. According to a microarray analysis, the expressions of approximately 971 genes were two-fold up-regulated by FPX treatment for 2 days. Among these genes, 598 genes were also induced by auxin/cytokinin, while 373 genes, including metabolic regulation-related genes, were specifically expressed only under FPX treatment. FPX can promote callus formations in rice, poplar, and several vegetables. FPX should be a useful tool to reveal unknown mechanisms of plant development and to increase the number of transgenic plant species.
SeriesOverallDesign: Total RNAs of the 4-d-old wild-type seedlings treated with 2.26 M 2,4-D and 0.46 M kinetin  for 0, 2, and 8 days. The total RNAs were used for microarray analysis to reveal genes affected by the FPX treatment to compare with auxin and cytokinin treatment.
SampleTitle: 0d-r1

SeriesTitle: FPX is a Novel Chemical Inducer That Promotes Callus Formation and Shoot Regeneration in Plants [auxin & cytokinin]
SeriesDescription: Auxin and cytokinin can regulate callus formation from developed plant organs and shoot regeneration from callus. The regulation of dedifferentiation and regeneration of plant cells by auxin and cytokinin stimulation was considered to be caused by the regulation of reprograming of callus cells, but the hypothesis had been argued still in now. Although elucidation of the regulatory mechanisms of callus formation and shoot regeneration has helped advance plant biotechnology research, many plant species are intractable to transformation because of difficulties with callus regulation. In this study, we identified the compound Fipexide (FPX) as a useful regulatory compound through chemical biology-based screening. Compared with the activity of auxin and cytokinin, FPX showed higher efficiency as a chemical inducer in callus formation, shoot regeneration, and Agrobacterium infection. In regards to morphology, the cellular organization of FPX-induced callus differed from that produced under auxin/cytokinin conditions. According to a microarray analysis, the expressions of approximately 971 genes were two-fold up-regulated by FPX treatment for 2 days. Among these genes, 598 genes were also induced by auxin/cytokinin, while 373 genes, including metabolic regulation-related genes, were specifically expressed only under FPX treatment. FPX can promote callus formations in rice, poplar, and several vegetables. FPX should be a useful tool to reveal unknown mechanisms of plant development and to increase the number of transgenic plant species.
SeriesOverallDesign: Total RNAs of the 4-d-old wild-type seedlings treated with 2.26 M 2,4-D and 0.46 M kinetin  for 0, 2, and 8 days. The total RNAs were used for microarray analysis to reveal genes affected by the FPX treatment to compare with auxin and cytokinin treatment.
SampleTitle: 0d-r3

In this study, we identified the compound Fipexide (FPX) as a useful regulatory compound through chemical biology-based screening. In regards to morphology, the cellular organization of FPX-induced callus differed from that produced under auxin/cytokinin conditions. According to a microarray analysis, the expressions of approximately 971 genes were two-fold up-regulated by FPX treatment for 2 days. Among these genes, 598 genes were also induced by auxin/cytokinin, while 373 genes, including metabolic regulation-related genes, were specifically expressed only under FPX treatment. FPX can promote callus formations in rice, poplar, and several vegetables. FPX should be a useful tool to reveal unknown mechanisms of plant development and to increase the number of transgenic plant species.
SeriesOverallDesign: Total RNAs of the 4-d-old wild-type seedlings treated with 45 M FPX for 0, 2, and 8 days. The total RNAs were used for microarray analysis to reveal genes affected by the FPX treatment to compare with auxin and cytokinin treatment.;	;	The 0 day samples have been re-analyzed from GSE116937-- the raw data are identical but the normalized values differ.

SeriesTitle: Expression data from Arabidopsis seedlings expressing a synthetic oxygen sensor device
SeriesDescription: Gene expression was compared between 7-day old seedlings expressing two effector modules of an oxygen sensor device,consisting of the Saccharomyces cerevisiae Gal4 activation domain (AD) fused to the human HIF-CODD and the Gal4 DNA binding domain (BD) fused to the human pVHL, and seedlings expressing the previously described effector modules in addition to the sensory module constituted by the human PHD3 gene under control of constitutive promoters
SeriesOverallDesign: Seedlings were individually genotyped by PCR to identify double and triple overexpressors,  before RNA extraction and hybridization on Affymetrix microarrays
